The meat pizza and the special- Hawaiian with horseradish mustard sauce were pretty nice.  Service was attentive and I liked the friendly nature of the place.  This place must be something special for they have their own zippy important looking driveway en route to the airport- a little tricky to leave but easy to get in.  Big parking lot sufficient to be able to skirt the beer stunned Madisonians wandering out clueless into the cars...  Prices are reasonable- once again you can take a bazillion Madisonites out to brunch or lunch or drinks or dinner for under $48 when the same services in LA would run you $150....  Secret for LA folks: flying out here plus food/drink bills is so economical- don't let your Madisonians travel to LA- promise you will meet them here and you can still afford to eat.  Just keep emphasizing that this lovely city has all one could ever need and it should work.  No seriously- my husband still tells the story from 2012 of a Madison bar tab we had of just $7.50 for drinks for 3 people and he gesticulates and his eyes bug out. I love Madison (when not sleeping in my boots under a dog or two).

Decent beers served in typically disappointing brew pub style. what is it with brew-pubs? Great in theory, but in reality the food and service never live up to the beer. This one is like a motor-sport themed Chili's. If that sounds awesome to you, have at it, rawkers.   Someone *probably* associated with the place, a user named Bill T with no reviews just one "tip" about how the Ale Asylum is not the Great Dane (?) and is not "cookie cutter" because the servers have "their own personality" (or something)  just sent me a rude personal message after I gave a less than adoring review. Surprisingly that failed to improve my opinion of your mediocre pizza or service.

Finally had a chance to make it over to the new location--pretty awesome!  For what it's worth, I think they are, without a doubt, the best brewery in the entire state.  Cool digs, free pool and great beer. They had a one-off on tap when I went--a very drinkable session beer which (I think) was classified as a Belgian pale ale. It was nice, had subtle hints of coriander and orange, and was totally delicious. Ballistic was the standout--you know, because IPAs are where they shine.  I will absolutely go back for food. Until then--Ale Asylum's brews will continue to remain in my fridge.

I love this place.  The beer is always good, the food is tasty, there are plenty of servers, and it's conveniently located.  I also like it because it is HUGE.  Even on a busy night you can easily find a table.  They have a massive capacity and are great for groups.

Came here for the beer and decided to get a bite to eat. WOW was my burger perfect! It was a bacon cheese burger with a Sriracha ketchup and some type of aioli. Asked for pink and was cooked perfect. I'm always afraid to order burgers because so often they come out overcooked or dry. Our sever was very friendly and very knowledgeable about the beer selection. I tried a Belgian IPA and the session IPA and love them both.

Seriously great beer.  I did the sampler while I was there.  There was not a single beer I didn't like, and the servings were much bigger than on the usual sampler.  Madtown Nutbrown, Diablo and the banana-y Hefeweissen were delicious. Very limited food selection.
Great burger, best I've had in awhile, alot of beer selection, fast service, no fries or cheese curds but everything else is good

Went to Ale Asylum back in March during a brewery crawl with my boyfriend and it quickly became one of our favorite breweries! We each ordered a flight of beer; there were so many beers on tap we couldn't even taste them all in two flights! One thing though, before ordering, we wish we would've known that the flights would be the biggest ones we've ever seen!! We are used to flights having either 2 or 3 ounces in each pour with 5 or 6 pours. At Ale Asylum they treat you GOOD and give you 6 pours of 6 ounces each! Please let me state that I am not complaining about the size of the pours! But knowing this, we probably would have started off with one flight and ordered a second later if we still wanted one. Since this was already our second brewery for the day and we were running on no breakfast or lunch, it took us a while to drink them all, so the second flight started to get a little warm. Totally our own fault, not Ale Asylum's. At this point we desperately needed food and since it was my first trip to Wisconsin we ordered the Wisconsin Bread Cheese appetizer. The "bread cheese" on the appetizer menu is very misleading because there is no bread. It's 6 little triangles of cheese  (about the size of a laughing cow cheese package) served with jam, honey, and almonds. Don't get me wrong, it was delicious, but at this point we really needed some carbs and were hoping the "bread cheese" would suffice this. If you order this, and I do recommend it, I would also order something with some substance like a pizza. At one point a bartender dropped a 6 pack of beer right in front of us and my boyfriend joked, "that beer is for free now, right?" The lady looked up at us and said "heck yeah it is" and gave us the five bottles that didn't break for FREE! We told her we were kidding and she insisted we take them because they couldn't be sold after they've been dropped, so they would be garbage anyway. So nice! Later the same bartender gave me a small sample of a Bloody Mary she was making for another customer because I told her it looked delicious. Seriously, one of the best Bloody Mary's EVER! If I hadn't already had a flight of beer I would have ordered one. This place is awesome. The flights are huge, the staff is amazing, and the beer is good! I can't wait to go back!!!

Love this place!  The service was just ok.  I know that the later it gets, the earlier a server wants to get out of there.  But honestly, it was 8 pm and our server asked us if we wanted our check like three times.  We were drinking.  Our tab was over $70.00.  What the heck.  Now the food is surprisingly delicious.  I ordered the chimmichurri (sp?) steak salad. Naturally GF.  I love not having to modify!!!  It had nice flavors, was cooked well and was actually filling.  Dinner salads are kind of a toss up.    For a beer place, the wine selection is pretty good.  I kind of wish, the wine was a little cheaper.  It is just Wollersheim.  Overall, I would definitely recommend this place.  OH! And it is right near the airport!  Always better than eating fast food before or after a pick up or drop off.
Food was great, bloody mary and long island were awesome. Yeah I ordered a bloody mary and long island at a beer place... deal with it.

You probably know Ale Asylum because of Hopalicious, Madison's (and much of Wisconsin's, and now Illinois') favorite Pale Ale (an American Pale Ale, but no one will give you a hard time if you call it an IPA).  It's worth it to pay a visit to the home of this and the other great Ale Asylum beers.  You'll get a nice variety - they're a pretty diverse ale brewery - and the chance to have some beers that are only available on-site.  These used to be referred to as the "Asylum Limited" series, but now they're giving them each their own name, so if you want to try a limited release and you don't know their beer list like the back of your hand (you don't??), just ask your server about the Limited.  I'll be (somewhat) brief on the beers, because the best way to experience these is to drink them, not read reviews ;)  They have a really broad range of ales: I've brought a lot of people here with varied tastes, and everyone has been happy.  On the hoppy side, there's the aforementioned "official beer of Madison," but be sure to look for Ballistic, and, if you're not driving, operating heavy machinery, or about to make an important decision, get a Satisfaction Jacksin if they have it.  For dark beer fans, Contorter Porter (used to be called Disporterly Conduct in the old days) and Big Slick Stout are great representatives of their styles.  The various Belgian styles are all done very well and worthy of your attention.  This is the second facility they've operated in their relatively short life so far, and it's massive.  There's a large, high-ceilinged main bar area (this can get a bit loud - not a bad thing, just something to know), a quieter, more restaurant-y dining area, and a separate bar area upstairs.  When the weather is nice, the place to be is outside on the patio!  While the menu isn't extensive, there's something for everyone with a nice list of pizzas (made for them by Falbo Brothers) ranging from traditional to unique, soups, salads, and sandwiches.  Unlike a lot of brewpubs, they don't operate a fryer, so have some chips and salsa with your sandwich, or go healthy and get the greens.  You are having beer, remember!

Stopped in today for a beer and some food.  The beer was good enough, but the food was just okay.  I had the BBQ pulled pork sandwich and a cup of their soup of the day which comes with beer bread.  All were okay, but I did really like the smell of the beer bread.  It didn't taste especially beery, but had a nice smell to it.  The sandwich was pretty standard, not bad, but not great.  I'd stop back in, seems like a fun enough place.  One thing I did notice is that all their pizzas are just frozen pizzas, and that actually makes up a large part of their menu.  If they worked on their food more, that would be awesome, but I can understand if that's not their primary goal.

Fantastic beer and food! Saturday night, no wait, not because it's bad but because it's massive! We sat on the large and beautiful patio. Fresh flowers, super clean, truly wonderful! The beers are great. I had the big slick stout, smooth and chocolaty, with hints of coffee. My husband had the unshadowed, more of a wheat beer, fruity, light and refershing. The menu doesn't have many options but it was diverse. There is something for everyone and it's spectacular! I had the Buffalo Chicken. They marinate the chicken in their beer, slather it in buffalo sauce and blue cheese something, fresh greens and an amazing bun. So delicious! My husband had the BBQ pulled pork and immediately smiled with the first bite. The sauce was tangy and sweet, again delicious! Served with chips and salsa. The salsa was also delicious. Our chips were slightly stale but I still hoovered them.   Service was good, she was polite but no overly friendly. We had everythìng that we needed but did find ourselves waiting a while for our check after our meal. Nothing major, but we were tired and ready to go home, even laid the card out on the table. She didn't take the card but left to print our bill before taking the card, despite me trying to hand it to her. Again, not a big deal but we were tired and eager to get home.  We will be back and I would still recommend this place to anyone.
The beer? Killer. The food... Meh. The pizza, while local (Falbo Bros), is pretty pedestrian... Although the pulled pork got rave reviews from my party. Go for the beer... The rest is gravy.

Went there for a tour on a Thursday - based in Internet and website info.  Got there and tours were only on Sundays.  Cool windows gave us a peek at the process, so - okay...  Had a couple of great beers.  Food was very good and priced nicely for the quality.  Service was spotty, borderline bad(ish).   Heavily tatted Hipster staff was a little haughty with us, we were older than most patrons.  Asked for a little extra salsa (very good) for the chips and was surprised to see it brought out as a side and charged $1.50.  That did not set well.  Overall recommended, good beer garden, if a little noisy from the traffic, but would return, given the right set of circumstances.

More a review for the product itself, since I haven't stepped foot onto the actual premises (yet). I'm sure that'll change next time or two I head out to Mad-town to visit one Mister Corey D...  Review! Ale Asylum! Wisconsin beer!  ... you betcha it is, and it's flippin' tasty, to boot.  In all honesty, I wasn't a super-fan at the beginning. I think the first brew I tasted was the Ambergeddon, and I was sort of one the fence about the whole thing.  Enter: Satisfaction Jacksin. Game over. Double IPA for the win. I mean, I do love double IPAs as a rule of thumb, but this one is up there. It's in the top ten, and that's a big deal. It's really good.  Follow: Contorter Porter + Madtown Nutbrown = delightful and drinkable darker brews for fall and winter months. (I'm a seasonal drinker, what can I say?)  Can't wait to visit the brewery itself, take a tour, and get even better acquainted w/ the Ale Asylum family of suds!

We stopped in here after visiting The Great Dane brewery. It's not near as relaxed and cool as the Great Dane was. The staff was pretentious and rude and the beer was just okay. We drank our beer and moved on, no need to waste any more time than necessary in this place.

The beer: Awesome. These guys are a staple in Madison and I loved visiting them at their old place. I like that they throw a new "Limited Asylum" beer into the mix once in a while as I enjoy trying new things.  The (newish) Digs: Cool building/atmosphere and nice patio space.  The Food: Basic menu leaves something lacking. I thought the menu was going to improve since they opened, but unfortunately this was not the case. I have had the pulled pork and the beef sandwich. The chips and fresh salsa are amazing.  Lots of bike parking!

My group agreed. This was our favorite stop on our trip to Madison. Sunday starting at 12 running every hour (until 4 or 5?) Pay five dollars for a pint and a tour of the brewery. Such a delight and the best/friendliest/most intimate tour in Madison. Took us incredibly close to show us equipment, fun stories and thoughtful/passionate/generous tour guide (possibly the owner?). Unique aesthetic. Beer holds up too!

They had 9 beers on tap and we chose to do the beer flight which included all of them in a generous size sample.  It was 18.00 for the flight which comes out to only 2.00 per sample which is a pretty good deal.  We had never purchased their beer before and we were pleasantly surprised.  We really enjoyed the gold digger blonde ale, hatha-weizzen, mad town nut brown, and bedlam.  They have a nice bar area with a couple tables and also bench seating area.  They have shirts, pint glasses, hats, etc for sale.  A t-shirt cost us 18.00.  I also noticed some hard liquor choices available at the bar.  They are expanding this fall of 2012 to a new location.  The plan looked really nice with a great upper and lower outdoor patio area.  We will definitely have to make another trip to ale asylum in order to see the new place.

Great beer.  If you love IPAs this is your place.  Satisfaction Jackson may be my all time favorite beer. Watch the  ABV  because many of the beers are potent.   Great food: their kitchen used to be limited to pizza and apps but they recently added a more extensive menu with creative sammies.  Several good vegetarian and vegan options as well.   Fun atmosphere - but no TVs.  If you are hoping to watch the game here better BYOD to stream it over the  free WiFi.

Ale Asylum runs a very informative tour which includes a pint of your-choice beer and a smaller sample about halfway through - all for $5.   You have to buy tour tickets in person. We showed up at 2:40 on Sunday, paid our $5 and were touring by 3:00. I called ahead of time to make sure there were spots available.   It wasn't the most fun brewery tour I've ever been on (Lakefront in Milwaukee) or the most in-depth and personal (Capital in Middleton) but I'm glad I went and I am happy to support local breweries. I'm sure I'll be back to hang out in the tasting room.
Not really my type of atmosphere but the beers and food are great and so was the staff there. thats why im giving it 4 stars.

I've been left with mixed feelings about eating here again. The food,  what there is of it is undeniably well prepared and imaginative. What it is not, in any way, is  generous for the price.  This is a bar after all,  not Alinea or some NY mecca of haute cuisine. I say that because beer and its filling properties will constitute the large part of what is a satisfying meal here.  Alone,  the pizzas and entrees  will fall short. My wife and I decided to split a salad that was described as having beef as its protein source and a pizza. Now I knew from having eaten here before that pizza is a relative term. Here it is a thin cracker crust, no more than 8 ounces , very well done but still a $12  menu item that is really an appetizer in size so we were counting on the salad to round out the meal. What we got with our very fresh baby spinach, dressing on the side, dried cranberries and cubes of roasted squash etc.( A very nice idea I should add) were 3 slices of beef (medallions) with a sprinkling of melty Parmesan cheese which were approximately 1 1/2 " long and about an inch wide with a thickness about 1/4" thick.   This is on a $12 salad. Since we split it,  when the waitress brought the pizza and asked us about the salad,  I commented that 3 pieces of meat between two people is a problem. I was informed that the salad was designed for one diner.  One diner the size of a squirrel might have been dissatisfied let alone,  one human. You could feel the chill come over her as her first thought her tip was in jeopardy instead of thinking of providing us with some satisfaction.  So we know what we're talking about here , I made a salad for myself the next day with some grilled chicken breast and for the hell of it cut 3 slices of meat approximating the sizes of the 3 slices of beef I'd seen the day before and put them on my digital scale. I was thinking maybe it'll be 2 ounces. It came to an 1 1/4 ounces.   Restaurants are not in the food business. they are in the hospitality business so when the patron points out that they think they're getting a gun stuck in their ribs,  an appropriate response isn't to wise off.    I realize protein is an ongoing issue for restaurants and their bottom line. Why else would high end places be coming up with dishes that emulate meat ? When one considers steaks of charred roasted cauliflower, confit of carrots etc. the answer is, "meat costs more than vegetables,  dummy."  None-the-less when you're located in a suburban area of Madison, Wisconsin,  your overhead isn't a New York overhead. Though I've enjoyed the place I'm up in the air about ever going back.

Been here twice and horrible service both times. My first visit with my boyfriend and his friends we ended up spending over 125, easily. We were there two and a half hours. Not because of hanging out but because they kept walking past our table.   The second time the dude kept looking at us then started helping other tables. I was done. I'll never go back to this place.

After an initial service issue was resolved our experience greatly improved. The waitress brought me a great flight of beers that I thought were great and even my wife enjoyed 4 of the 6 beers (she's not a beer drinker). The Spinach/Artichoke Dip could use a little more cheese in it but it was still very good as we wiped out the dip far before we wiped out the chips. She ordered the Bacon Cheeseburger which was FANTASTIC with plenty of cheese and bacon and a very tasty beer reduction sauce and caramelized onions.  I ordered the Grilled Cheese sandwich with two types of Wisconsin cheese on grilled sourdough. It was the perfect duo to split between us and each of us ordered the bacon clam chowder soup as a side which was delicious and I will be attempting to replicate at home.

What a difference a month makes. A month ago I left a bad review after a culmination of several visits/experiences - Ale Asylum's response to my concerns were swift and immediate - I received contact from Hathaway and Jillian. They took time to listen and even referred me to Otto, co-owner, who asked me to visit with him. Their collective concern was genuine and meaningful. I was impressed and grateful that my comments and concerns were invited and respected. Yesterday we stopped for a mid-afternoon sandwich, served at the bar. The welcoming and charismatic attitude was infectious from the start. It was nice to see staff and patrons enjoying themselves, the great beer, and excellent food - served with enthusiasm and genuine interest. Kudo's to Hathaway, Jillian, Otto and everyone at Ale Asylum - the beer you create is something Madison and Wisconsin can be proud of, your food has always been creative and tasty, and yesterday your staff made visiting Ale Asylum fun again. Thank you. I look forward to visiting again soon. Take a few minutes to visit Aly Asylum and enjoy the experience - I believe you will. Ask about the new brewery tour.

If you're in town and have a rental car, this place is an excellent stop prior to your trip home. It's super close to the airport so you can drink in peace without feeling like you're going to miss your flight after you get stuck in traffic.   I got a sampler, which has six of their beers for $15. It sounds pricey, but the samples are huge (6oz I think). Personally, I'd rather have smaller samples so that the last one wasn't completely warm by the time I got around to drinking it, but it's not my brewery. :)  The beer was good, not the best I had in Madison, but all very hoppy. I think this backfired a bit, making their beers seem a bit one-note, but they were good beers overall.   The place was hectic and busy, and seemed a bit understaffed for the crowd. But our bartender did a good job of managing it and was friendly and helpful.

The beer here is great.   We also ordered lunch.   We were assured that we would have enough time to eat.  The food service was slow....  but the food was great.  My friend got the Philly cheese steak sandwich and I got the pad Thai chicken sandwich.   I haven't been able to stop thinking about that sandwich since I had it.  I am not local, would like the recipe so I can have again.  Brewery itself wasn't too spectacular.

First off, I am giving this review three stars instead of the two stars I REALLY want to give, just because it is related to service and food only--not the beer. This is a brewery, so beer is their #1 concern(as it should be) and it shows.   I don't drink beer, but the others that were with me do, and said it was good. The beer is four stars, but everything else is two stars at best.  The service was horrid, and the food was mediocre. We were seated outside, and they were understaffed because they had "technically closed the deck for the season", as our server told us. It took forever to be able to order once we were ready, and we waited somewhere between 30-40 minutes after we were done eating just to be able to get the check and LEAVE. We went inside to flag someone down to get boxes, and she said she'd bring them--and didn't. So, one of us went inside to get them.  I ordered the beet salad. The menu lists "spring mix, roasted beets, roasted corn, chopped onions, and pistachios...lemon juice and olive oil, topped with goat cheese'" I got no pistachios, or nuts of any kind. They added mandarin oranges, and the greens were SO overdressed that the salad was soggy within five minutes. Seriously? If your menu states specifics, I expect THOSE things on my salad. For $12, I expect accuracy, and not a limp salad that i just push around the plate. I would have said something to our waitress--if I had ever seen her. Two others got the pizza, and it wasn't horrible, but not something we'd order again.   Bottom line: I won't be back, but might send people here for post dinner beers.

Good beers, decent atmosphere, skip the food.   (+/-) The atmosphere screams motorcycle bar with lots of steel and metal work.   (+) The beer was great. We sidled on up to the bar and did a flight (nice big pours (+)), but the food was lackluster (-). The shrimp ceviche was disappointing and service was pretty average, but this place beats Great Dane hands down for more creative and interesting brews.

This was my first time stopping in at Ale Asylum.  My initial plan was just to top off a growler but decided to stay for lunch.  I had my baby in tow and did not have a problem having her with me while we ate lunch.  It is very obvious there is a local crowd of regulars during lunch.  Mary was tending bar and was just what I expected growing up in a small town where the barkeep knows everyone and has no filter.  We had great conversation and excellent food.  I had the Asylum burger and my friend had the Cuban. My burger was advertised as 1/3 pound but I would guess it was pushing 1/2.  It was huge and delicious.  I enjoyed the chips and salsa.  The salsa was on the thin side but had good heat.  I was told the Cuban was delicious as well.  The beer was outstanding too.  I would have had a flight if I was not in charge of a baby for the day.  The only downside is that they did not have a changing table for the baby.  I understand their clientele is usually Over 21 years old not under 21 months but on the flip side it is a restaurant.  In the end I will come back drink more of their beer and eat more of their food.

I have been slowly, but surely, falling in love with Ale Asylum. Their beer is always great. I've tried at least 3/4 of their normal selection over the past few years and a good chunk of their special brews. They all vary on the goodness scale, but that's probably due to personal taste. I've never once had anything I didn't enjoy drinking.  The tour is pretty good as well. Not quite as good as some of the Milwaukee tours I've been on, but they're pretty hard to compete with. The tour guide I had was fun and informative. I would definitely recommend it if you have an interest in seeing what goes on in the brewery area or learning about how beer is made.  Now, here's where they won me. My friends would drag me here every now and again for various reasons. I was always pretty average or even disappointed (I'm looking at you, catfish poboy) on the food. That is, until I tried their burger. Holy crap, I could never praise that burger enough. I will go on for the rest of my life knowing that I've had the best burger of my life at the age of 25. If I ever move I will tell the tales of how I'll never have the best burger of my life again. Or I'll make sure to visit Madison just for this burger. I have no idea how they do it or what's so different, but I don't care. You could tell me this burger was made of kittens and I'd still be a monster and eat it. It's really that good. I'm not sure if it's the chef or the recipe, but I always go in at night on Sunday, Monday, or Tuesday. Don't ever change the recipe. And if it is just the cook, give that person a raise.  Go in. Order a burger. Order a beer. Rejoice in your perfect life choices. Repeat.
If you are there and the daily special involves pork belly...ignore the menu. Have that. Today, for Thaco Thursday,  they knocked it out of the park! Well done Adam and crew!

If I could give zero stars I would. Love the beer, hate this place. Went there for a friend's birthday and a really nice (not ale asylum) beer was given to her as a gift. They confiscated it! It was unopened, and was going to stay unopened. They didn't ask us to take it to the car or anything, they just took it! They also wouldn't let us eat home made birthday cupcakes. They seriously need to lighten up. They are in my opinion one of the best breweries in Wisconsin and they treated us terribly.

Very cool restaurant space, really decent food, and cool shiny brewing equipment. Bonus option: brewery tour!  There is an upstairs lounge area with lots of cozy seating, a bar, and you still have access to the full menu.  I've only stopped in a couple of times, but I can definitely recommend their tacos and the tempeh pita. Yum!  I categorically hate all beer, but friends have said that their beer is very good and they offer a wide selection so you can never get bored even if you are a regular.

Had an awesome bartender, the beer is good (lots of variety), and they also have pilot batches you can try! It's also really nice that it is close to the airport, so you can get your friends a beer when they first come into town or right before they leave!

I love their beers. I had their brown, porter and stout... all excellent. The food was really good too, especially considering that they have not really been in the serious food business for a while. I feel like I should give them 5 stars because they are not trying to do too much, but their menu is still a little limited. In the end, how can one not like a place that makes a point to let us know that all of their beers are vegan.

I'm pretty surprised by all of these negative reviews. We stopped by for some beer and dinner after we landed across the road in Madison.  It was setup with the seat yourself option that night so we took a tour around both floors to see what this place was all about. The place is huge and there are different vibes depending where you sit. The upstairs has a smaller bar with a couple tables. It seemed quieter and a little classier up there. The downstairs has a huge bar area with pin ball and high tops as well as a nicer dining room.  We opted for the downstairs bar so we could interact with the bartenders and learn more about what they had to offer.  I enjoyed the Contorter Porter and Madtown Nutbrown. I also had the Asylum Burger which I thought was great. Everything comes with chips and salsa unless you pay an extra dollar for other sides.  One of the owners was actually at the bar and we struck up a conversation with him. It was very interesting to learn his style of brewing and how they create the different flavors we were tasting.  I'd definitely recommend checking this place out.
Unbelievably awesome place. Beer is good, but the atmosphere and layout is amazing.

Decent late night ears. The menu is modest but decent. The hot beef sandwich was good. I also ordered a cup of chicken noodle soup. The soup was clearly house made and loaded with chicken. Actually more chicken than noodles. Companions had hummus plate and chips and salsa. Both were generous portions and looked pretty good.

The concrete walls are the coolest part of this place. In a close second is the service. Coming in at third, sadly, is the beer.  Full disclosure: neither hubs nor I are lovers of IPA. This brewery offers mostly IPA which leaves our options scarce.   There's not an option on the menu for flights so we asked our waitress and she confirmed they do have them! Shew! 6 good sized beers for $15, it's pretty fair. You get a sheet to fill out with your choices and out they come.  The brown ale is really the only one I remember trying that I actually would've ordered more of. Everything else was either meh or gross. I shadowed was straight up disgusting.   We called ahead to make sure it's a toddler approved establishment and they said yes but they only have 2 high chairs. For a place that has a decent dining area, you'd think they'd be more accommodating to families. I guess I'm just spoiled by my local breweries.   AA, you have potential if you mix up the menu better and throw some family friendly options around. Probably will skip you for now, though.
Delicious beers, great tour! A good variety of unfiltered and pure ales. Have not tried the food, but would like to next time.

Strong showing of Belgian-style ales in a pleasant atmosphere. These are definitely their strengths, but other beers are well done as well.  Their house-made salsa is a plus, but the extra charge for more salsa is a little bit of a downer, particularly when they give you so many chips that it is supremely obvious that the dip they give you is not enough. That's a bit disingenuous.

Ale Asylum was our backup choice for lunch when the first place was closed due to a kitchen fire.  Well let me say that in hindsight I am not disappointed we had to go here.  I enjoyed a flight of beers with my husband.  The Hopalicious is one of my favorites!   For lunch I had the spicy peanut salad with chicken.  The flavors were great and I felt like I got a good portion!  Plus it evened out the beer I was drinking nicely.  The flavors in the salad were good although I could have gone for more "spice" in my spicy peanut sauce!   The tasting room was pretty empty while we were here.  We came with a big group and had no problem getting a table and our server was great!

If this is an asylum, lock me up and throw away the key. As cheesy as that sounds, let me tell you that this place is completely legit. On our trip to some Wisconsin breweries, this was the second one that we went to. I had a sample flight and had one or two of the choice drinks in there. It was incredible and I think "Why isn't this as as world renowned as the 3 Floyds hype?" It is unknown if I ever return but if I had the power of teleportation I would visit on a weekly basis. My hat goes off to the staff and brewmasters at Ale Asylum.

After reading all the glowing reviews for this place I'd be a fool not to bookmark and plan a future visit!  I did just that and once again Yelp community I thank you for another recommendation because this place was great.  There were a few things that I didn't completely dig but all in all I had a great experience.    I went here on St. Patrick's Day and for some reason I didn't think that would be a problem.  Get this however, it wasn't.  After being somewhat disappointed that this place was more of a restaurant and less of an actual full on brewery with tours we went to the front to get a table.  Even though this place was packed we were seated right away.  As I walked to the table I remarked to the hostess how busy they were and she noted that for a Saturday they were actually pretty light.  I made a mental note to not try this place on a Saturday lest my idea of this place change.  Anyway, we were seated and greeted almost immediately by our waitress.  She was nice, tatted and fit with the cool decor of the place.   We started our meals off with the nachos and I ordered a light wheat beer.  The beer was actually really good.  My disappointment however was with our appetizer.  First I think the nachos with the salsa were $4 or so which of course isn't bad.  They also bring a huge portion of nachos which was great!  What they don't do is provide nearly enough salsa.  I mean it was tiny.  It was so tiny that we would have needed at least 4 more to finish the nachos off.  And of course when we wanted additional salsa there was an additional charge of $3 which is damn near the price of the nacho basket.  It seems kind of sneaky to me.  If you want me to eat less nachos don't bring so many.  If you want me to pay more for nachos just increase the price. Don't seduce me with a large nacho basket with salsa that isn't enough for a quarter of the basket.    My other gripe with this place is that when they brought my side salad which by the way was really good they didn't even ask me what type of dressing I wanted.  I am not sure if it is because they only have one type of dressing or if she forgot to ask but either way I ended up with ranch even though I would have preferred Italian.  With the salad dressing it was the same issue with as I had with the salsa.  The little black condiment container they use was only half full yet I had a pretty decently sized side salad.  There seems to be someone in the back who is somewhat stingy with the condiments.    It sucks that this place had those types of issues because it really marred what could have been an excellent dining experience.  With all that said however the fish tacos that I had were top notch!  They were perfectly seasoned and the tortilla was nice and warm.  The man ordered some kind of flatbread burger that he really enjoyed.   He did however have the same gripes that I had though his major gripe was that he considered the portion size to be a little on the small side. I think restaurant portions are getting out of control anyway so I had no beef with the portion size.    Would I go here again?  That is a great question.  I think so.  I really enjoyed my dish and loved the beer.  I would however stay away from the nachos and see if I could somehow finagle my waitress to provide a full serving of the Italian dressing.

Top three high/lowlights  1) good microbrews 2) gluten free options available 3) inexpensive  Went to Ale Asylum for lunch on a Saturday and was seated right away. I can't drink beer but Ale Asylum brews are well known in Madison and get great reviews. Our server was really nice and got me a gluten free menu right away. Unlike some places, the gluten free menu shows you not only which items are already gluten free but also how you can make substitutions to other items to make them gluten free. I ended up getting the ham sandwich on gluten free bread with a cup of the soup of the day (split pea). My friend got the pulled pork sandwich and a salad. We both thought our meals were good but nothing super special or note-worthy. Overall, I think Ale Asylum is a great place to meet up with people for a drink and apps but maybe look elsewhere if you are looking for a great meal.

First time here as I was back home for the holidays. I must say, I'm impressed with all of the breweries that have been opening up in the Midwest.   Ale asylum is good stuff. Went there last Friday and enjoyed a couple different brews. Namely, the blonde (not really my thing, but well crafted none the less.), and the demento, a pale ale with a firm taste, but really smooth. It's always nice to enjoy something that isn't an IPA, especially since here in California it has been the rage for what seems like forever.   Next time I'm in town I'll have to give the stout a try.

I guess I keep in mind that this is primarily a brewery, not a restaurant, so I think the food is outstanding.  Smallish menu, but the pizzas and salads are really tasty.  Beer is great!  (OK, Sticky McDougal is off-style, since they use belgian yeast in this scotch ale, and it tastes like it.  Why? Why? Why?)  Tasters are freely given and decently sized, and bartenders actually know details about the beers (ingredients, style differences, etc).

I've had a couple of visits to this place over the last couple weeks, and I'm decently pleased.  I think the staff is what really sold it to me above anything else.  The bartenders have been consistent, on top of what they do, and have remembered us each time (which may or may not be for bad reasons).  The menu isn't anything out of this world, but it hits all the marks you'd expect at a brewery, such as pizza, sandwiches, etc, but oddly, no burger (although I might've just missed it somehow).  The pizza was fair, and the cheesesteak and seafood tacos were really good, but I'm not a fan of the salsa (needs more umph).  I'm curious about the duck poppers and the PB WTF, but I keep ending up there with the pickiest of eaters, so I'll just have to ignore them at some point.  A nice perk is that they have a full bar.  God knows that not everyone is a beer drinker, so this keeps them viable as an after work option.  You'd think that everyone in the military likes beer, but you'd be sadly mistaken...and disappointed.  On the note of beers, AA has a solid selection of brews and the pricing is pretty decent for the selection.  Between ambiance, the staff and the beer, they've replaced the Great Dane as my bring-people-to-a-brewery place.  Especially given the ease of parking out this way instead of downtown.

Beer- You can't go wrong here.  If you like beer, they have something for you.  However, if you don't  know exactly what you want, it can be difficult to get them to help.  They are beer experts, not everyone is.  When I've brought people who don't know what to order and they ask for suggestions some of the answers fly right over their heads.  Food- Pizzas are the best thing to get here.  I've tried several other menu items and they have been... ok.  Besides, what's better than pizza when drinking beer?  Atmosphere- Very fitting for a brewery.  Always busy.  Large bar which is nice because I typically want to belly up to one when I'm in a beer mood.  Easy to find and tons of parking.

This place is insane. I'm really sorry we didn't do the actual tour now after spending the day drinking here. The beer is all great and the service was fun. The food looked good but we decided to eat elsewhere. If you are anywhere near this area this is absolutely a brewery worth making the trip to!

this is by far my favorite local beer. the location of the brewery/restaurant is a bit weird, but the place itself is pretty solid... cool decor, friendly bartenders and (duh) great beer. the menu is small but everything is yummy.  i am anxiously awaiting the return of their tripel nova.
Yeah it's okay. If you have extra time cause a flight  is delayed, it makes sense. So so food, so so service. Definitely not my first choice.
Great beer and better service! If you're lucky you can catch Mary behind the bar. Always friendly, and quick with a beautiful smile. No tvs is a plus.

I have now been here two consecutive times with fantastic service!  Friendly and knowledgeable.  If it keeps coming, so will the stars.  Hopefully they got rid of the other life-hating bar manager.  Thanks for stepping up the service Ale Asylum!
It's hard not to like this place.  Wood fire pizza and tasty craft beer.
One of my favorite breweries period. Both good and beer address great, service is excellent as well. You could try all the beer on the menu at any given time and not find a bad one.

This place had pretty decent food and there beer was fantastic but our server last night was one of the worst servers Iv ever had. I was honestly scared to order anything else being afraid he'd do something to my food / drink, he acted so annoyed when I asked for beer suggestions and generally gave off the most hostile vibes while talking to us, will most definitely never be back

So beer is my thing. I'm a west coast guy who loves big, west coast IPA that are dry, bitter and filled with glorious hops. This place is probably the best in southern Wisconsin so hence the 4 stars. They have 4 different IPAs and a double that is good. Super close to airport and makes it an easy place to wait for the person you are picking up and grab a quick beer. The food is good too.

Good place to grab a beer and an appetizer! It's a little pricey but it's worth the taste and atmosphere. My favorite appetizer is the duck appetizer! Forgot what it's called but it's spicy and super yummy! I also got a flight of beer and they have a variety of good tasting beers from light to dark, and hoppy. Love the outdoor seating too but wish I could have had my flight outside instead of inside, that's the only thing that sucks.

I've had nothing but delicious experiences at Ale Asylum.  Scrumptious pizzas, sandwiches (good cheese!), and most importantly, BEER!  So many to choose from!  Try them all (and be sure to hire a cab to take you home)!  Why go to McD's or The Sports Pub nearby when you get something so much better just across the street?  They also have a great pool table, comfy sitting areas, a nice smoking patio... and cute bartenders!

I never went to the old Ale Asylum, but have been a fan of their beers for a long time. Hopalicious is one of my go-to beers, and Ambergeddon is another fantastic beer.  I headed out to the brewery two weeks ago with a friend of mine I haven't seen in a while. I happened to have the specialty brew when I was there which was the Blood Red Ale. I also happened to have three of them. Believe it or not but this wasn't my first beer, but you'd have thought it was after drinking those in a small window of time.  The brewery/tasting room has their neat art/beer designs up on the wall. The bartenders are quick and courteous. While I did not eat when I was there, I did notice (before those beers took effect that is) their waitstaff seemed to move quick as well. The way the kitchen is set up is a bit awkward, as you can see into as you walk in. The back portion of the dining room also has an awkward amount of open space that needs "something" back there.   All in all, I had an incredibly enjoyable evening (not sure I had to reiterate that part) and will be back. I am just not a fan of the haul it is for me to get out there, and if I plan on those three beers again, I am going to need to make more friends that don't love beer as much as I do.

From the outside AA looks like one of those modern church-cities.  You know, an over-sized joint large enough to land a jumbo jet in.  OKay..AA isn't that big..but it's much bigger than the average bear (or brewery).   Inside, the space isn't quite as evident.  There's a main bar area and a separate restaurant area on the first floor.  Additional seating is available upstairs.  We sat in the main bar area as it's kid friendly.  After hiking Devil's Lake for 7+ miles, we were hungry and thirsty.  I had a long drive home and could only allow a half glass so I went with the Contorter Porter.  This was delicious and I badly wanted to inhale the thing, but take driving seriously, and we had two hours ahead of us.  Turning my attention to food, my son and I both had the bacon cheeseburger.  I ghosted the thing in double quick time given my hunger.  Did the same with the mashed potatoes.  As a side note, next to our table was a very cool photo of some Air Force planes that were sponsored by AA.  Each pilot signed the photo and there's a letter of thanks to AA for their support.  Ironically, on our way out of AA, we passed the airport and these same planes fired up their engines and took off right before our eyes.  Just a cool moment, and unique timing I guess.   I'll look up AA again when I'm in the neighborhood.   Cheers!

For a brew pub they seem very fond of order. I met friends who were biking here and the host was quite concerned we not congregate by the door. There was a free table by the door, but it only had 6 seats and it was a party of about 11, and they didn't want some of us standing. It's a bit strange to have a brew pub to commit to being sit-down service. They do have an upstairs outdoor patio, so we were able to enjoy the late afternoon sun, only slightly marred by a couple of smokers. They didn't have staff service on the upstairs patio yet, but you could go inside to the small bar and order food. Trouble is, they were "changing over the menu next week," so they were out of at least half the menu options, including, I kid you not, the bread and cheese plate. Chips and salsa/guac were about all that was left besides fried mozzarella sticks and a strange peanut butter 'dipping' plate. I passed on the remainder of the options, which might not have been a bad idea, as my friend thought the pulled pork was dry. Another friend liked the fish tacos but with a jalapeno aoili, I had to pass. Beer was okay--I tried a small glass of the Ambergeddon which did indeed have a bitter aftertaste (as described). The Bamboozelator was delicious.

Always good food, beer and service here.  Chips and Guacamole are a great starter and then we had the cheese bread.  Sad they didn't have Contorter Porter on tap as its one of my favorites, but with so many other options it's easy to pick something else.  Sat out on the patio and had a nice evening.

Interesting place to grab a beer and enjoy the ambience of the brewery.   You can view the process of making beer through the windows in certain spots of the place.    Names of the beers are pretty cool.   Big serving of food dishes. Typical bar food.

Ale Asylum has some solid beer choices with a nice range of styles in the taproom. The tour is a nice interactive tour. Menu looks good though have not eaten there yet. May go again for a tour, will definitely be back again for the taproom. Love the decor of the entire place.

Beer Ipa and seasonal Ipa. Black bean burger just ok. Wish their patio was dog friendly, or at the least, fenced differently so you could leash dog on outside of fence.  Friendly service. Inside is cool too. All new!!
Great craft beers.  Try the havartti  and ham sandwich, it's awesome!

Came here for the $5 brewery tour and was not disappointed. The price included a full, pint-sized sample of any tap beer and a 45 minute (that actually ended up being 60 minutes) guided tour.   The tour went through the entire brewing process and we were able to walk through the brewery while it was in production. We sampled beer that was brewed 5 days ago and then beer that was brewed 14 days ago so that we were able to understand and taste the difference.   The tour guide ended up being one of the owners and it was evident that he is very knowledgeable in the brewing process. He encouraged questions and thoroughly answered each one.

Although I had a less than satisfactory visit here during the summer, my latest visit has fully redeemed them :-)  I recently attended the Gail Ambrosius 10th anniversary chocolate and beer pairing event with a couple of friends. Oh. My. Goodness. First of all, the entire event was free, and the chocolates and beer sample pours were varied and plentiful. If you got there early enough, you could mention the secret code words, and Gail herself handed you a ticket good for a free pint of your choice, as well. There was even a door prize drawing. Wow. Fantastic!  It was very well attended, and a bit warm, but given the cold snap we've had, that was welcome. I'd never been to the upstairs before, and it's really nice up there. Comfy red couches, tables, and big windows, and quieter. A perfect place to sit and chat and sip. And I found a new favorite Ale Asylum brew, Ballistic IPA. Bright and citrusy, just the way I like it.

Really weird industrial park location.  Maybe it's easy to get to if you're familiar with Madison public transit, but I'm not, and it seemed a bit boonies.  ANYWAY, if you're not an alcoholic looking to get trashed this shouldn't be a problem... it's not exactly far from anything, just not exactly near much either.  Except a meat testing facility.  More on that later.  Must give kudos for being an independent brewery.  Beers were solid, but not outstanding.  Food choices were not many (4 options, of which 2 were depleted).  I liked the pizza we ordered but my boyfriend wondered if it was a frozen Tostinos.  But it's about the beer, not the food.  They have couches.  I like couches.  They have a free pool table, I like free AND pool tables.  They have a patio.  I like drinking my beer outside, except when it's in a cloud of smoke and accompanied by wafts of what our waitress told us was a smell coming from the meat testing plant next door.  GROSS!  What the hell is that about?  I've got a high tolerance for the unsanitary and am far more comfortable at a dive than a high class joint, but that wigged me out a bit.    Moral of the story: good, not great beer.  Stay inside, or get your beer to go.

The service here is pretty terrible so keep that in mind when deciding whether not to dine here. We ordered beers and flights & chips and guacamole when the server got distracted for a minute. She left and came back. We told her never mind on the chips as we realize we can get them as a side with our meal and she told us we couldn't take it back even though it was just ordered a minute before.  The duck poppers were ok, the chips and guacamole were meh, The adult grilled cheese sandwich was good and the Mac n cheese was good. The food was pretty hit and miss.  Our waitress continually picked up our plates before we were done eating and even took half a beer off the table when my friends snatched it back from her. She also had BO.  Everyone liked the beer.

Awesome place to begin your visit to Madison, located just as you exit the airport. They have tons of seating, both inside and on a large outdoor patio. The food menu has lots of yummy choices, either for appetizers or entrées. This visit, we shared a spinach dip plate, which was tasty.   As for the beer, we'll I don't think you can go wrong with any choice. Just to be sure, I did a flight, which consisted of a choice of six beers served in generous sized (looked to be 6 oz) tasting glasses. While Hopalicious is their signature beer, everything else was really good too.

We finally got the chance to tour the facilities, and I must say I am impressed with the current scale of production!   The tour is $5 a head and includes a free pint of any beer on tap and a free tasting. The single beer available for tasting is really at the discretion of the tour guide, although I had hoped to be able to sample a full flight of their beers on tap and wouldn't have minded paying a little extra for that. They did let us sample what the Happy Ending tasted like before and after conditioning though, definitely an interesting, and educational, juxtaposition.  I liked that the tour took us through the entirety of the brewing facility, allowing us to get up close and personal with the brewing vats, malt hanger, and the likes - I've been on a number of other tours where we weren't really allowed to walk around the equipment and see them up close, and I felt like that really cut down on the experience.   Finally, our tour guide was fantastic! He did a great job of explaining the brewing process, and was awesome about fielding questions from the audience. Unfortunately, we did have a few obnoxious members in our tour group that made the experience less enjoyable, and I would have liked to see the tour guide regulate the loud side conversations a little better. Oh well.  Ale Asylum is such a great place to spend a few hours on the weekends - I can't wait to be back to try their menu!!

Came here immediately after landing. I was bummed out by their flight selection bc they had about 15-20 different drafts on the list but more than 50% were crossed out bc they were considered seasonal. Nevertheless, the ones I chose were good and HUGE. Service was good and the atmosphere was laid back.

A whole lot of hoppalicious has been drank by this guy right here.  The food was never something I really went to Ale Asylum for, but it is pretty tasty if you need something to soak up the booze.  Great seating, and nice big bar area, as well as big tables to hang out with relatively large groups.

I love local brews and spent a Saturday with my dear friend checking out a few breweries around the area. Ale Asylum was my least favorite, mostly because the beer is "beer beer" it's boozy, hoppy, and packs a serious "thwap" to your insides. I'd come back if I had friends who wanted to check it out, but wouldn't necessarily come back on my own volition.

If I could give this place more than five stars I would, I mean I really would. It is just that good! (Is anyone as excited as me about the completion of their renovations?)   This place has some of the best beer on the planet, you may not find that your particular beverage of choice is on tap, but just like food, beer is seasonal. For me it is all about their belgians...strong, tasty, and ultimately dangerously tasty. For those who simply can't decide where to begin, they have sampler platters available.   Also, they have some of the most hard-working bartenders I have ever seen here! They must have type caffeine+ blood because they just don't stop. Don't hesistate to ask a kind question, they will let you know everything about that beverage while simultaneously pouring you a sample and straightening your tie.   They also offer some good, simple dishes here at very reasonable prices. Pizzas are great because they are so shareable and always have such fresh and unusual ingredients, although they offer soup and sandwiches as well...  With beer this good you could serve it to me in a leaky basement and I would still give this place five stars! (Of course their facilities are impeccably clean and lovely!) Drink beer here; this is all you really need to know.

This is an updated review.  Last time I walked out after not being waited on.  This time the service was quick and friendly.  I ordered the bacon cheeseburger and they serve chips and salsa as the side.  I have never seen this before, but I will roll with the punches.  The burger was great!  Very large patty and very tasty.  The salsa was very good with a medium thick tomato base.  The only disappointment was the chips.  They were cheap and tasted like something from a bag.  Too bad, because the salsa was so good. Overall the food was very good.  However, towards the end of my visit the waitress disappeared and I had to wait to close out my ticket.  My ticket before tip was $14.00.

I'm happy that America has made a name for itself in the brew world with their brand of crazy-hoppy IPAs.   Unfortunately, IPAs are usually too bitter for my pallet, and my distaste for them has made me question my patriotism.  It has also kept me from venturing to the West, land of the IPA, more than once a year.   Thankfully, Ale Asylums IPAs have taught me a thing or two about IPA appreciation.  Somehow, their IPAs have all the hoppyness without any of the grapefruit-esque bitters.  I don't know how they do it, but I'm all aboard their train. choo chooo
Great beer, forgettable food. Terrific beer sampler. The food is pub style food and isn't bad but not worth going for without the beer
Beer was good and the food was really good. We had duck popppers, quinoa burger, wings, bacon cheeseburger, pulled pork sandwich, artichoke dip. Nice building and plenty of space

I like you Ale Asylum, I do. (Sorry it took me so long to tell the world).  I just returned from Woodman's with some bottles which reminded me I have yet to write a review for your space.   First of all, it's HUUUUUUUUUGE! 43,000 square feet I believe. And I've heard they have the ability to expand with demands to well over 100,000 square feet - nuts! While they weren't yet brewing/bottling when I was there, it was still cool to walk the floor and eye over the incredible machinery that blankets the space. Strategically placed windows mean you can see a part of the operation from almost anywhere in the tasting room and tables and chairs are laid out in a way that makes the place feel open and airy (which it is).   Now let's get one thing straight here fellow Madisonians. It's a tasting room, it's not a restaurant, it's not a bar, it's not a nightclub, it's not a lounge, it's a tasting room. I'm bemused by reviews that single out the food as not being so great... just go there and drink! If you're looking for some fierce food head to one of the bajillion restaurants that serve Ale Asylum on tap. The place is for trying taps, chatting with co-workers, letting your hair down... I don't think it was built with the intention that it was going to win culinary awards with a cornucopia of food options for every palate.   I dig the Ale Asylum orange paint that's long given them a hip edge, there's a cool commissioned mural on one wall and outside when it's warm are awesome planters that were made locally with reclaimed wood.   All in all, it's a great place to chill after work or er, uhm when you should be at work!

Ale Asylum is a unique stop near the airport. I tried a beer or two and wasn't super impressed (tasted soapy to me), but the food was pretty good. I ordered shrimp tacos and they were great with their cheese sauce. I would possibly go back again to give this place a second try, since it seems to be a favorite of some locals.

We stopped in for a couple beers and an appetizer. The 12 oz. Curl was a quality choice; however, all four of our beverages came far warmer than you would expect. As for the eats, the Smoked Pork Quesadilla was just average - by no means bad but not memorable.  The outdoor seating is a big plus, which keeps it a solid three-star location. I know it's 4-star on most visits. We'll be back soon to see if that's the case.

I'm not a beer connoisseur by any means, but this place definitely has some unique brews. I tried the 10% Triple Nova and the Ambergeddon and both were fantastic. I didn't give this place a 5 only because I was there for a short time and I don't feel I'm an expert on this style bar, but if you're looking for good beer this is definitely a place to stop.

I organized a meetup at the Ale Asylum, and just as a heads up, they do not accept reservations.  This means they don't care if you have a group, they will do nothing in preparation.  We had to put tables together for ourselves, and since there was no host, we had to direct people to our table. Service was good, and I was amazed that our waiter managed to get everyone served, even as they came in staggered.   The food...the food was not good.  It would have been one thing if my food wasn't good, but every person at the table shrugged their shoulders and said, "Meh'.  Burgers are served pink or no pink, which apparently means raw or done.  I upgraded for an extra $1 to get bean dip, and it had no flavor at all.  None.  We got the pepperoni and salami flatbread pizza to share, and it had no salami. It's a beer place, and I don't drink beer, yet I had 2 cider ale's that I enjoyed.  It's a good place for meeting a couple people for drinks.  But eat first!

The Big Slick Stout is great.  I had the Cuban along with others who had the pulled pork, pizza, and ham and cheese and everyone liked every bite.  The wait staff was very friendly and informative about the menu and the area.  A great place to take family, friends and or clients.

I finally visited the Ale Asylum's new location! I met friends for a drink and dinner. I am always a fan of Ale Asylum's beers - Hopalicious & Mad Town Nut Brown are my favorites.  I was pleasantly surprised with the food. Our group had fish tacos, a southwest salad, and a pulled pork sandwich and there wasn't a bite on any of the plates at the end of the meal!   Ale Asylum is a great place for happy hour & snack/dinner for sure!!

I've been going to Ale Asylum for years now, and with the new menu change I'd like to recommend some options to people.  Spinich Artichoke Dip is TO DIE FOR! They serve it with this rosemary bread that is out of this world.   The adult grilled cheese is also on this heaven bread, and it is delicious without being too filling.  Staff is always super friendly and attentive, I've never had a bad experience here.

I have been a fan of Ale Asylum beers for quite a while, but finally made the trip into the brewery after a group of a dozen people all coming in from out of town deemed in the best place to meet.   It is a big building that is easy to get to and has plenty of parking. Granted, it was 1:30 in the afternoon on a Thursday, but we pretty much had the run of the place the whole time we were there. I think they had 15 of their different beers listed up on their wall above the bar, with a few more options on a special menu. It was cheaper to order pitchers than pints, and we went through quite a few of those. Their standards are top notch, including their Madtown Nutbrown, Hopalicious, and Bedlam, but I also got to try quite a few that I haven't seen elsewhere, including some seasonal and even some experimental batches. At least when I was there, the focus seemed to be strongly towards pale ales, but they certainly had something for everybody. I don't remember the exact numbers, but their flights were much more expensive and came with much more beer than I wanted for a flight to use as a sampler.  The food menu wasn't big, but everything sounded great. They had a variety of appetizers, salads, sandwiches, and a decent variety of pizzas. They also had a few special offerings that were listed on a board up front. I got the spicy BBQ chicken pizza, which was more than enough for 1 person. The crust is super thin but very crispy, and the ingredients on top were delicious. The rest of the food also got good reviews, and the price point is pretty much just on par with what you would expect.  Our waitress was fantastic, and kept up with our large table without any issues. She was also very helpful in making recommendations about beer or food. We made things difficult at the end of lunch by splitting up checks in a weird order, but that was no problem for them either, and was very convenient for our large group all ordering lunch and pitchers.   I will definitely be back here the next time I am in Madison, and hope to be able to catch them for a tour of the brewery.

I am not a hophead.  You can count the number of beers i drink in a year on both hands.  This place combines the Teutonic quality and thoroughness typical in Wisconsin with the MadTown coolness.  Great beer--great food nice place good service.  Was there as the Badgers were moving into Final Four--good news--no TV

Great food, great beer, easy parking.  This restaurant will appeal to anyone who enjoys hearty food and wants to experience a local brew, maybe even a flight of 12 different local brews.   Prices are reasonable (June 2018) with most dishes priced around $11-$13. Beer is at the upper pricing end at around $5-$7 per drink.   The atmosphere at lunchtime was very relaxed. We were able to seat ourselves and a waiter was around to help us quickly with menus. Even though there are not a whole lot of choices on the menu, deciding what to order may be quite a challenge as all the food sounds delicious.  When my food was served, it was a meal for someone who is hungry. The walleye po boy sandwich had great flavor and everyone was very satisfied with their meals.  I ordered the Dumb and Dunkel which was excellent and highly recommended. If you enjoy a smooth beer, this is for you.  You can't go wrong if you eat here.

This is more of a college hangout setting. It is VERY LOUD. I have gone here a couple times to experience the decor. You can see where the beer is being made too which is kinda cool. The food is just okay. The Staff is freindly.

Went here with my boyfriend last weekend and loved it, tried the beer flight of 6. Not really into dark beer so I stuck to the light ones which were nice. I liked their Gold Digger. We plan to go back soon!!

A few of the great things about living in Madison are the huge selection of fantastic local beers and amazing restaurants. Ale Asylum has definitely found a winning combination in their new building - serving up some of the best beer in the country and offering a great selection of delicious sandwiches, pizza, and snacks to go with it.   It's loud, busy, and rather insane some nights - but definitely worth it for the ridiculous selection of their own beer they offer on tap.   Few things make a long, hard, week come to an end better than a fresh pint of Mad Town Nut Brown and that is ultimately what will keep me coming back time and time again.

Great idea. Great product. Too busy to function. I felt like an afterthought. Then a fly got in my drink and the bartender got mad when I asked for another. I politely explained that I just didn't feel comfortable drinking it and she replied "it's protien, it's not going to kill you"   Sorry I don't drink bugs.   Save ur money. This place is all for show.

I enjoyed my time at Ale Asylum on a rainy Saturday afternoon with some friends and family. The two beers I ordered were refreshing, light, and crisp--exactly what I was looking for in an afternoon beer but nothing to write home about. I knocked off one star because the food was not impressive at all. I tried the Thai shrimp salad wrap and some of my friend's catfish po'boy. Sorry to say it but I was disappointed. The shrimp was chewy and didn't taste very fresh, I hardly ate it. And the po'boy was blah, forgettable. I was sad to see they don't serve fried cheese curds, boo!!!!! They also have a sad selection of sides...no fries?! What in the world!? Tortilla chips are your only option unless you upgrade to soup or a side salad. I don't think I'll be passing by here again anytime soon, but I wouldn't mind picking up a 6-pack of Demento (btw they have cool & fun beer names) if they have it bottled or canned anywhere!!

Cool. All good. Good beer and cool place to hangout.    Try any of the hoppy beers or my fave, the Heff. Then sit outside for some sun or inside to get a view of the brewery in progress.    We didn't eat but menu seems good.  We did however try the pecan smokeys which are chocolates made with beer wort and chocolate made with beer wart, dark chocolate, and sprinkled with pecans.   Service is good but be ready for an onslaught of hoppy beers.

If there was a 6 star option I would rate Ale Asylum as such. Although I have not been able to get to the newer location, I still know that it is worth going to. the following will be based on the original location and the beers. Mostly the beers. The former location was not really huge, but was arm and inviting. A semi formal bar and an impinger. You know, that thing that cooks pizzas and sandwiches on a conveyer belt. food options weren't the best, but I was not there for the food. I could have been there for the free pool on the table though.  On Saturdays they had tours. I have a friend that frequents Wisconsin often and when I hear tale that she is going back, I salivate. I get giddy and my hopes soar for the greatness that I shall receive upon her return. My fave: Hopalicious. Simply put a hop centric ale with a floral, pine bouquet that is just fantastic   Ambergeddon: The phrase "My Amber beat up your IPA" had me intrigued and I really like the malt forward clean hop finsh. the color, as the name suggests is a nice reddish gold.  MadTown Nut Brown: Really mellow, semi malty. Hazelnut undertones. Better than Newcastle, Thirdstone, etc...  Contorter Porter: Not my style, but akin to Anchor Porter in terms of quality  Ballistic IPA: This is a newer brew and while good, is more like Rampant IPA and seems thrown together to satiate the thirst for west coast IPA.   Satisfaction Jackson: Double IPA. Delicious and perfectly balanced malt and hop. I would love to grab cases of this any time I go through  Tripel Nova: 10%ABV. You are limited to only 2 glasses of this if you visit. It is dangerously good. Just try it!  Bedlam IPA: Pretty perfect in terms of what you are looking for. Just enough malt, but a lot of hop. I love it.  The labels for Ale Asylum were designed to be cool enough that if you got them tattooed on you they would still be appreciated. I would never put a Bud Light Lime tatt on me, but if I was more inclined for a beer motif, Ale Asylum would have no problem going on my skin. Labels don't make great beer, though Ale Asylum does.
Enjoyed a lunch pizza that had unique flavors and was baked to perfection. Unique thin crust that was their special recipe. Friendly wait staff, great experience.

Good selection of beer.  I recommend the Mad Town Nut Brown.  Service is good and they have a good selection of food to choose from which is a plus from some other breweries.   Highly recommend this place. Stop while in town.
Been here one time for beer sampling...was neat and friendly place ....good selection of beers ..like to go back again.

Came to the Ale Asylum on a weekday for lunch and a drink. There were plenty of places to sit, and I ordered a beer and a cheeseburger. The burger comes with chips and salsa, which was different, and I think I would rather of just had french fries as a side like most places offer. The burger was great and I had no complaints. They offer a large variety of their own brews and have brewery tours on Sundays. They have a large outdoor patio that gets pretty busy in the summer months. Overall happy with my lunch here and will definitely come back for food or just drinks.

Lotsa great beers to choose from, and plenty of space to sit, one of Madison's biggest breweries, sadly didn't get to try any of the food but oh well. I tried the Babadook beer (amazing title btw) as well as the hopalicious and the hashalicious. My friend got the Dr Vennum and I tried, also good. The board with all their beers is pretty big and lit up. The servers were nice. If I'm ever back in Madison I would definitely go back. Located pretty much in the heart of the downtown area

This was my first time here and I was blown away. The service here (both our waitress and the bartender) were so great...good conversation and suggestions along with speedy service and even bringing us an extra table because they thought we might need more room. My friends greatly enjoyed a very generous tasting of 6 different beers and really loved almost all of them. I enjoyed a cider with my meal. For a starter I got a bowl of the soup of the day which was jalapeno bacon clam chowder which had incredible flavor and was hearty with plenty of clams to be enjoyed. For my meal I went with another special (tilapia fish tacos) and was very impressed with the seasoned, blackened flavorful fish with a wonderful avocado sauce to accompany the taco. However I have to say my favorite part of the meal was hands-down the chips and salsa that came with my meal. I am a sucker for chips and salsa and the salsa they serve is unlike anything I've had with a slightly smoky flavor it is so enjoyable and super addictive. I will be sure to be back when I visit Madison again.

First of all, all the beer is vegan!  Winning! The beer flights are huge, so make sure you have someone to share with. There a a couple vegan food options on the menu too! Though I wasn't too hungry so I stuck to house made guac and salsa. It was awesome! Make sure to ask to sit in Doug's section. Super nice, fun guy. Awesome server.

Just opened new facility is AWESOME.  First of all, I love beer. They have it all: plenty of different kinds to try and all brewed in house.  Second of all, the food is pretty good too (although we weren't planning on going for the food). They have tons of vegetarian options and it's much tastier than the sparse offerings at other breweries.  The atmosphere is awesome and is perfect for a mid-day treat or a Friday night out.  Overall, I highly recommend stopping if you haven't yet.

i had to kill some time near madison's airport so decided to stop by the ale asylum to enjoy the beautiful july evening outdoors with a summery beverage. the tripel nova, a belgian-style tripel, was the perfect brew with its bouquet of spice and hint of sweet citrus flavors.  this was the perfect thing to do to set me in the right mood to welcome back two teenagers home after a couple weeks of being without them. (seriously though, i love 'em and have missed them but will miss the peaceful evenings at home with just my lovely wife.
A regular stop on our way to Madison to visit our daughter.  Ballistic IPA is a solid IPA, available in six packs or growlers.

The Ale Asylum has many of the things one would be looking for in a local brewery/taproom:  - Quality regular and seasonal brews (usually 8-10 on tap at any given time) - Very friendly bartenders and staff - A comfortable bar and lounge area with pool, couches, etc. - A cozy patio with an abundance of hops encompassing the deck and walls  Other than the somewhat isolated location (though that will be changing soon) and forgettable food (the focus here is on the beer, which is just fine) there's really not much that could be improved upon.  Cheers!

Stop here every time I fly into madison for some good beer. Had time to sample some grub today and it was amazing.  The menu consists of your normal items;  burger,  steak sandwich,  pizza,  etc but the name is the only thing it has in common with other pubs.  Not your typical pub grub by any means. Had a salad special that blew me away and followed it up with a pizza like I've never had before. Just awesome. Don't know what 5 star chef they kidnapped and locked in the kitchen but he/she is doing a great job.

Right off the bat, I would like to say that our waitress, Jordan, was amazing! Had a great time there in part because of her happy attitude and her patience with our slow progression. We just wanted to relax and have some good beer, and she was great with that. If management is listening - Jordan is a star!  Okay, so the beer was really good. I am a pretty picky beer drinker, I'll be honest. So I usually only find a few beers at each place that I like, while my husband will like most of the menu. I tried three beers up front and liked all three immensely. I LOVE mixing beers, so typically I will order a mixed pint of the mixture that tastes best, but this time I liked the individual beers so much, I simply got two half pours plus an empty glass. That way I could drink each beer individually and have the mix as well. It was delightful!  (I mixed the nut brown with the contorter porter - it was amazing!)  We ordered a bit of food - my man had the beer cheese soup and I got the chimichurri chicken salad. His soup was delicious. My salad was also very good. It had a TON of chicken on it, and I ha been expecting more greenery, so I was surprised. I think it needs one more element to be perfect - maybe more tomatoes, maybe a light vinaigrette on the spinach, maybe pickled carrots - I don't know but it is missing something.  Next time we go to Madison I will definitely come back to try the grilled wings - I was SO tempted this time, kinda wish I had.   My man had a massive flight of six beers - seriously healthy pours, and he loved all the beers he tried. Plus we had an aged imperial stout that was really good. Apparently right now they are tapping one aged beer a week but when it's gone, it's gone. We got one of the last glasses of this one - it would be fun to go each week and try the new release.  Overall, I'd be a regular if we lived locally. For now, if we visit Madison, we are pretty likely to show up there. Four solid stars with an extra one for Jordan. Go, Drink, Enjoy!
Great place with wonderful beer. The menu is decent if not spectacular.

Beer has been decent in my visits, but have only eaten here one time because of the poor quality that time.  (Had bruschetta) Service at the bar is hit and miss, mostly aloof and inattentive.  With so many great places nearby, can you afford to put off customers?

Really nice space and atmosphere. They have a nice beer selection of their own beer. They also sometimes have beer they are testing out that you can try. My husband loves the beer, Bedlam is probably his favorite. Its nice that you can try a lot of their beers and then go buy them at the grocery store!  We've also had dinner once here and it was really tasty. It was with a large group and I remember service being good. The lighting is a little dark and that bothered some people in our group but not me. They have a nice selection of sandwiches. They also have salads and a couple soups.   They have a good size bar and there is also bar seating at some high top tables. Service is pretty good and we are always checked on frequently.
Beer was great! customer service sucked!!! We did like the Wisconsin bread cheese appetizer to die for and great combination

Located right off the airport, this is a great first stop after a day's worth of flying!   Our flight was delayed and we didn't get in until 10 PM. Lucky for us, it was the weekend and Ale Asylum still serves their pizzas until Midnight! The thin crust made with brown ale was appreciated. We tried one with goat cheese and one with BBQ chicken. Both were good. There was also a pizza-like order of garlic bread that made me happy.  The beers are good. They ranged from decent to above average, but they were good to just sit back and enjoy. My favorite was the Triplel Nova (which they served in a pretty big tulip glass.) The Hopalicious is solid. We tried the limited release Phantasm, but wasn't a huge fan.
